sen.j: 吉備津彦命（きびつひこのみこと）は日本神道の神 (神道)。
sen.e: Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto is a god in Japanese Shinto (Shinto).
Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto is a Shinto god.
sen.cmt: "in Japanese Shinto (Shinto)"→"Shinto" and moved - since Shinto only exists in Japan, I think this suffices.
sen.e: Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto is a Shinto god.

sen.j: 吉備冠者（きびのかじゃ）ともいう。
sen.e: He is also called as Kibi no Kaja.
He is also known as Kibi no Kaja.
He is also known as Kibi no Kaja.

sen.j: 孝霊天皇の皇子で山陽道を主に制圧した四道将軍の一人。
sen.e: He is Prince of Emperor Korei and one of Shido Shogun (generals dispatched to four circuits) who mainly suppressed Sanyodo.
He was a son of Emperor Korei and as one of the Shido Shogun (four generals sent to the four regions the country was divided into) who mainly suppressed Sanyodo.
sen.cmt: "is Prince"→"was a son"Added "as", "the""dispatched to four circuits"→"sent to the four regions the country was divided into"
sen.e: He was Emperor Korei's son and was dispatched to the Sanyodo region as one of the four General Commanders to conquer the region.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 別名（本来の名）を五十狭芹彦（いさせりひこ）といい、吉備国を平定した事によって吉備津彦を名乗る事になる。
sen.e: He is also called as Isaserihiko (his original name), and by subjugating Kibi Province, he became to be named Kibitsuhiko.
Also known as Isaserihiko (his original name), he took the name Kibitsuhiko after subjugating Kibi Province.
sen.cmt: Deleted "He is""called"→"known""he became to be named Kibitsuhiko"→"he took the name Kibitsuhiko" and moved"and by"→"after"
sen.e: Also known as Isaserihiko (his original name), he took the name Kibitsuhiko after subjugating Kibi Province.

sen.j: （吉備津彦とは「吉備の勢力者」の意味）
sen.e: (the meaning of Kibitsuhiko is 'powerful man of Kibi')
(Kibitsuhiko means 'powerful man of Kibi')
(Kibitsuhiko means 'powerful man of Kibi')

sen.j: 一説にはこの時の逸話（温羅伝説）が桃太郎のモデルの一つであったとも言われており、吉備国のあった岡山県はこれをして自県を「桃太郎発祥の地」として広いPR活動を行っている。
sen.e: There is an opinion saying that the anecdote of that time (Ura Legend) was one of the models of Momotaro (the Peach Boy), and Okayama Prefecture, where Kibi Province was located, regard itself as 'the birthplace of Momotaro' and is taking wide publicity actions.

According to one theory, the story of Momotaro is based on an anecdote (the Legend of Ura) from that time, and Okayama Prefecture, where Kibi Province was located, promotes itself as 'the birthplace of Momotaro' as part of a wider PR campaign.
sen.cmt: "There is an opinion saying that"→"According to one theory,""the anecdote of that time (Ura Legend) was one of the models of Momotaro (the Peach Boy)"→"the story of Momotaro is based on an anecdote (the Legend of Ura) from that time""regard"→"promotes""and is taking wide publicity actions"→"as part of a wider PR campaign"
sen.e: According to one theory, the story of Momotaro (The Peach Boy) is based on an anecdote (the Legend of Ura) from that time, and Okayama Prefecture, where Kibi Province was located, promotes itself as 'the birthplace of Momotaro' as part of a wider PR campaign.
sen.cmt: 桃太郎を補足しました。

sen.j: 庵戸宮（やまとくろだいおどのみや、現在の奈良県磯城郡田原本町）にて父・孝霊天皇と母・倭国香媛の間に生まれたとされる。
sen.e: He is said to be born of Emperor Korei, his father, and Yamato no Kuni Kahime, his mother, at Yamato Kurodaiodo no Miya (present day Tawaramoto-cho City, Shiki-gun District, Nara Prefecture).
He is said to have been born to Emperor Korei, his father, and Yamato no Kuni Kahime, his mother, at Yamato Kurodaiodo no Miya (present day Tawaramoto-cho City, Shiki-gun District, Nara Prefecture).
He is said to have been born to Emperor Korei, his father, and Yamato no Kuni Kahime, his mother, at Yamato Kurodaiodo no Miya (present day Tawaramoto-cho, Shiki-gun District, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 一説には倭迹迹日百襲媛命が母（実際は姉）であったとも言われる。
sen.e: In one opinion, his mother is said to be Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto (actually, his older sister).
According to one theory, his mother is said to be Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto (although she was actually his older sister).
sen.cmt: "In one opinion"→"According to one theory"Added "although she was"Deleted comma
sen.e: According to one theory, his mother is said to be Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto (although she was actually his older sister).

sen.j: 四道将軍として腹違いの弟である稚武彦命と共に山陽道に沿って周辺域を平定。
sen.e: With his young half brother Wakatakehiko no Mikoto, he subjugated surrounding areas along Sanyodo as Shido Shogun.
As a Shido Shogun, together with his younger half brother, Wakatakehiko no Mikoto, he subjugated areas surrounding the Sanyodo.

He was dispatched to the Sanyodo region as one of the four General Commanders along with his younger half brother, Wakatakehiko no Mikoto, in order to establish the power of the imperial government in the areas around the region.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その大きな目的は吉備国制圧と同国の製鉄技術であったとされる。
sen.e: Its great object is regarded as the suppression of the Kibi Province and its steel manufacturing techniques.
A major reason for this is believed to be the suppression of Kibi Province and its steel manufacturing techniques.
sen.cmt: "Its great object is regarded as"→"A major reason for this is believed to be "Deleted "the"
sen.e: The major purpose of his expedition is believed to have been to conquer Kibi Province and to obtain its steel manufacturing technology.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: （和歌における吉備の枕詞には「まかねふく（真金吹く）」という語句があり、これが吉備国の主要産業が製鉄鋳造技術である事の裏付けであったと言われる）
sen.e: (There is a word 'Makanefuku' (blowing steel) as the makura word (poetic epithet convention) of Kibi, and this is said to be the evidence of the fact that the steel manufacturing was the main industry of Kibi Province).

(The word 'Makanefuku' (blowing steel), as the 'makurakotoba' (an epithet used in waka poetry) to describe Kibi, is said to be evidence of the fact that steel manufacturing was the main industry of Kibi Province.)
sen.cmt: "There is a"→"The""the makura word (poetic epithet convention) of"→"the 'makurakotoba' (an epithet used in waka poetry) to describe"Deleted "and this", "the", "the"
sen.e: (The word 'Makanefuku' (blowing steel), as the 'makurakotoba' (an epithet used in waka poetry) to describe Kibi, is said to be evidence of the fact that steel manufacturing was the main industry of Kibi Province.)

sen.j: 岡山県にて広く語り継がれている吉備津神社 (岡山市)の縁起物語によると、地域を荒らし鬼ノ城（きのじょう）に住む「鬼」である温羅（うら）を犬飼健（いぬかいたける）・楽々森彦（ささもりひこ）・留玉臣（とめたまおみ）という三人の家来と共に倒し、その祟りを鎮めるために温羅を神社の釜の下に封じたとされている。
sen.e: According to engi (writing about the history) story of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine (Okayama City) widely passed down in Okayama Prefecture, he defeated Ura, who was 'oni' (ogre) living in Kino-jo Castle and wreaking around the area, with his three retainers, Inukaitakeru, Sasamorihiko, and Tometamaomi, and to quiet his curse, he is said to have sealed Ura under the iron pot of the shrine.

According to the written history of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine in Okayama City, which has been passed down throughout Okayama Prefecture, Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto and his three retainers, Inukai Takeru, Sasa Morihiko, and Tome Tamaomi defeated Ura, an 'oni' (ogre) who lived in Kino-jo Castle and was terrorizing the area, and to break his curse, they are said to have sealed Ura under the iron pot of the shrine.
sen.cmt: "engi (writing about the history) story"→"the written history"Added "in"Deleted bracketsAdded ", which has been""widely"→"throughout" and movedDeleted "in""he"→"Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto""with his three retainers, Inukaitakeru, Sasamorihiko, and Tometamaomi,"→"and his three retainers, Inukai Takeru, Sasa Morihiko, and Tome Tamaomi" and moved"who was"→"an""living"→"who lived""wreaking around"→"was terrorizing""quiet"→"break""he is"→"they are"
sen.e: According to a historical story of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine in Okayama City, which has been passed down throughout Okayama Prefecture, Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto and his three retainers, Inukai Takeru, Sasa Morihiko, and Tome Tamaomi defeated Ura, an 'oni' (ogre) who lived in Kino-jo Castle and was terrorizing the area, and to break his curse, they are said to have sealed Ura under the iron pot of the shrine.
sen.cmt: 縁起物語→historical storyとしました。

sen.j: この家来たちを桃太郎の逸話に置き換えると「犬飼健犬」「楽々森彦猿」「留玉臣雉」となる。
sen.e: If these retainers are to be replaced with ones in the anecdote of Momotaro, they will be 'Inukaitakeru dog,' 'Sasamorihiko monkey,' and 'Tometamaomi pheasant.'
If these retainers are placed into the story of Momotaro, then Inukai Takeru becomes the dog, Sasa Morihiko becomes the monkey and Tome Tamaomi becomes the pheasant.
sen.cmt: "are to be replaced with ones in"→"are placed into""anecdote"→"story""they will be 'Inukaitakeru dog,' 'Sasamorihiko monkey,' and 'Tometamaomi pheasant.'"→"then Inukai Takeru becomes the dog, Sasa Morihiko becomes the Monkey and Tome Tamaomi becomes the pheasant."
sen.e: If these retainers are placed into the story of Momotaro, then Inukai Takeru becomes the dog, Sasa Morihiko becomes the monkey and Tome Tamaomi becomes the pheasant.

sen.j: また「釜の下に鬼を封じた」というのは、そのまま吉備津神社における鳴釜神事の縁起につながる。
sen.e: Also, the part 'sealing an ogre under iron pot' directly relate to engi of Narukama Shinji Ritual in Kibitsu-jinja Shrine.
Also, the part about 'sealing the ogre under the iron pot' directly relates to the origins of the Narukama Shinji Ritual of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine.
Also, the part about 'sealing the ogre under the iron pot' directly relates to the origins of the Narukama Shinji Ritual of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 実際には「温羅」とはそれまで吉備国を支配していた旧勢力に製鉄技術を供与していた渡来人もしくは地来の豪族であり、旧勢力に義理立てするために吉備津彦（ひいてはヤマト王権）と戦ったと言う見方がある。
sen.e: There is a view regarding that 'Ura' was actually toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) or local ruling families who were giving steel manufacturing techniques to old power who were ruling Kibi Province, and as a justice for the old power, they fought against Kibitsuhiko (or further, Yamato sovereignty).

There is a theory that 'Ura' was actually toraijin (immigrants, mainly from China and Korea), who had been giving steel manufacturing techniques to the former rulers of Kibi Province, or local ruling families, and out of loyalty to the former rulers, they fought against Kibitsuhiko (or Yamato rule).
sen.cmt: "view regarding"→"theory"Reworded middle of sentence to make less wordy, although the Japanese is ambiguous as to who exactly did what."as a justice for old power"→"out of loyalty to the former rulers"Deleted "further,"
sen.e: There is a theory that 'Ura' was actually toraijin (immigrants, mainly from China and Korea), who had been giving steel manufacturing techniques to the former rulers of Kibi Province, or local ruling families, and out of loyalty to the former rulers, they fought against Kibitsuhiko (or Yamato rule).

sen.j: 吉備国平定後はここを足場として讃岐国、出雲国にも進出したとされる。
sen.e: After subjugating Kibi Province, using the place as his foothold, he is regarded to have advanced to Izumo Province, too.
After subjugating Kibi Province, he is said to used it as a foothold to advance to Sanuki Province and Izumo Province.
sen.cmt: "he is regarded"→"he is said to" and moved"using the place"→"used it""his"→"a"Deleted 'd'Added "Sanuki Province and"Deleted ", too"
sen.e: After conquering Kibi Province, he is believed to have used it as a foothold to advance to Sanuki and Izumo Provinces.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: なお香川県においても岡山県と同様に桃太郎伝説が存在するが、この「讃岐桃太郎」の主役は讃岐国平定にて先陣を切った稚武彦命であるとされる。
sen.e: Further, like in Okayama Prefecture, there is Momotaro Legend also existing in Kagawa Prefecture, too, but the main character in this 'Sanuki Momotaro' is said to be Wakatakehiko no Mikoto, who lead the van in subjugation of Sanuki Province.

Further, like Okayama Prefecture, Kagawa Prefecture also has a Momotaro Legend, but the main character in this 'Sanuki Momotaro' is said to be Wakatakehiko no Mikoto, who lead the van in the subjugation of Sanuki Province.
sen.cmt: Deleted "in"Moved "Kagawa Prefecture"Moved "also""there is"→"has a"Deleted "also existing in", "too"Added "the"
sen.e: A Momotaro legend exists in Kagawa Prefecture as well as Okayama Prefecture; the protagonist in this Kagawa version of the legend is believed to be Wakatakehiko no Mikoto, who led the vanguard in the conquest of Sanuki Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 稚武彦命(下ツ道臣)は、兄の大吉備津彦命(上ツ道臣)とともに吉備の国に派遣された。
sen.e: Wakatakehiko no Mikoto (Shimotsumichi no Omi), along with his old brother Okibitsuhiko no Mikoto (Kamitsumichi no Omi), was dispatched to Kibi Province.
Wakatakehiko no Mikoto (Shimotsumichi no Omi) and his older brother, Okibitsuhiko no Mikoto (Kamitsumichi no Omi), were dispatched to Kibi Province.
Wakatakehiko no Mikoto (Shimotsumichi no Omi) and his older brother, Okibitsuhiko no Mikoto (Kamitsumichi no Omi), were dispatched to Kibi Province.

sen.j: 後に、稚武彦命が治めた土地には『笠』の地名が残る事から笠臣とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Later, since the place name 'Kasa' remain in lands where Wakatakehiko no Mikoto ruled, he is also called Kasa no Omi.
Later, since the place name 'Kasa' remains in lands where Wakatakehiko no Mikoto ruled, he also came to be called Kasa no Omi.
Since territories conquered by Wakatakehiko no Mikoto bear names that contain a Chinese character pronounced "kasa" in Japanese, he later came to be known as Kasa no Omi.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 吉備津神社の社伝によると、その後、吉備津彦は吉備中山の麓に茅葺宮を造って住み、281歳で亡くなって中山の山頂（茶臼山）に葬られたとされている。
sen.e: According to the biography of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine, after that, Kibitsuhiko constructed and lived in Kayabuki no Miya at the foot of Kibi no Nakayama Mountain, and when he died at the age of 281, he is said to have buried at the top of Nakayama Mountain (Chausu-yama Mountain).

According to the tradition of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine, after that, Kibitsuhiko constructed and lived in Kayabuki no Miya at the foot of Kibi no Nakayama Mountain, and when he died at the age of 281, he is said to have been buried at the top of Nakayama Mountain (Chausu-yama Mountain).

According to the tradition of Kibitsu-jinja Shrine, after that, Kibitsuhiko constructed and lived in Kayabuki no Miya at the foot of Mt. Kibi no Nakayama, and when he died at the age of 281, he is said to have been buried at the top of Mt. Kibi no Nakayama (Mt. Chausu).
sen.cmt: 吉備中山と中山を Mt. Kibi no Nakayamaとしました。

sen.j: この中山茶臼山古墳（正式名称：大吉備津彦命墓）は土地の人々には御陵や御廟と呼ばれており現在では宮内庁の所管地として管理されている。
sen.e: This Nakayama Chausu-yama Tomb (official name: Okibitsuhiko no Mikoto no Haka) is called Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) or Gobyo (mausoleum for nobles) by local people, and it is managed by Imperial Household Agency as a jurisdiction, presently.

This Nakayama Chausu-yama Tomb (official name: Okibitsuhiko no Mikoto no Haka) is called the Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) or Gobyo (mausoleum for nobles) by local people, and is currently managed under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.
sen.cmt: Added "the"Deleted "it""by Imperial Household Agency as a jurisdiction"→"under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency""presently"→"currently" and moved
sen.e: This Nakayama Chausu-yama Tomb (official name: Okibitsuhiko no Mikoto no Haka) is called the Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) or Gobyo (mausoleum for nobles) by local people, and is currently managed under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.

sen.j: 吉備津彦命の家来である犬飼健は犬養氏の始祖で犬養毅の祖先であると言われている。
sen.e: Inukaitakeru, retainer of Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto, is said to be the progenitor of Inukai clan and ancestor of Tsuyoshi INUKAI.
Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto's retainer, Inukai Takeru, is said to be the progenitor of the Inukai clan and an ancestor of Tsuyoshi INUKAI.
sen.cmt: "Inukaitakeru"→"Inukai Takeru""retainer of Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto"→"Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto's retainer," and movedAdded "the", "an"
sen.e: Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto's retainer, Inukai Takeru, is said to be the progenitor of the Inukai clan and an ancestor of Tsuyoshi INUKAI.

sen.j: 吉備津神社 -- 備中国の吉備津神社を頂点とする吉備津彦信仰の総本社
sen.e: Kibitsu-jinja Shrine -- Grand head shrine for faith in Kibitsuhiko, with Kibitsu-jinja Shrine at Bicchu Province as the top.
Kibitsu-jinja Shrine -- Grand head shrine for followers of Kibitsuhiko, headed by Kibitsu-jinja Shrine in Bicchu Province.
sen.cmt: "faith in"→"followers of""as the top"→"headed by" and movedDeleted "with""at"→"in"
sen.e: Kibitsu-jinja Shrine: grand head shrine for followers of Kibitsuhiko, headed by Kibitsu-jinja Shrine in Bicchu Province

sen.j: 吉備津神社 (岡山市) -- 備中国一宮
sen.e: Kibitsu-jinja Shrine (Okayama City) -- Ichinomiya, Bicchu Province.
Kibitsu-jinja Shrine (Okayama City) -- the supreme shrine in Bicchu Province.
Kibitsu-jinja Shrine (Okayama City): Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) in Bicchu Province
sen.cmt: -- → : としました。一宮→Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) としました。

sen.j: 吉備津神社 (福山市) -- 備後国一宮
sen.e: Kibitsu-jinja Shrine (Fukuyama City) -- Ichinomiya, Bingo Province.
Kibitsu-jinja Shrine (Fukuyama City) -- the supreme shrine in Bingo Province.
Kibitsu-jinja Shrine (Fukuyama City): Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) in Bingo Province
sen.cmt: -- → : としました。一宮→Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) としました。

sen.j: 吉備津彦神社 -- 備前国一宮
sen.e: Kibitsuhiko-jinja Shrine -- Ichinomiya, Bizen Province.
Kibitsuhiko-jinja Shrine -- the supreme shrine in Bizen Province.
Kibitsuhiko-jinja Shrine: Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) shrine in Bizen Province
sen.cmt: -- → : としました。一宮→Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) としました。

sen.j: 御崎（みさき、おんざき）神社
sen.e: Misaki, or Onzaki-jinja Shrine.
Misaki-, or Onzaki-jinja Shrine.
Misaki-, or Onzaki-jinja Shrine
sen.cmt: ピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 艮御崎（うしとらみさき、うしとらおんざき）神社
sen.e: Ushitoramisaki, or Ushitoraonzaki-jinja Shrine.
Ushitoramisaki-, or Ushitoraonzaki-jinja Shrine.
Ushitoramisaki-, or Ushitoraonzaki-jinja Shrine
sen.cmt: ピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 田村神社 (高松市) -- 讃岐国一宮。
sen.e: Tamura-jinja Shrine (Takamatsu City) -- Ichinomiya, Sanuki Province.
Tamura-jinja Shrine (Takamatsu City) -- Ichinomiya, Sanuki Province.
Tamura-jinja Shrine (Takamatsu City): Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) in Sanuki Province
sen.cmt: -- → : としました。一宮→Ichinomiya (the supreme shrine) としました。

sen.j: 讃岐の桃太郎伝説では、海賊に讃岐を襲われた倭迹迹日百襲媛命が対岸の吉備の国に進攻していた弟の吉備津彦兄弟に助けを求めたことが、桃太郎伝説となったと伝わる。
sen.e: In Momotaro Legend in Sanuki, it has been passed down that the incident of Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto, who had Sanuki raided by pirates, asking for help to her young brother, Kibitsuhiko brothers, became to be the Momotaro Legend.

According to the 'Momotaro Legend of Sanuki,' the origins of the Momotaro story lie in Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto asking her younger brothers, including Kibitsuhiko, who were on the opposite shore invading Kibitsu, for help in defeating pirates who were attacking Sanuki.

According to the 'Momotaro Legend of Sanuki,' the origins of the Momotaro story lie in Yamatototohimomosohime no Mikoto asking her younger brothers, including Kibitsuhiko, who were on the opposite shore invading Kibitsu, for help in defeating pirates who were attacking Sanuki.

sen.j: （犬-犬島の住人、猿-猿王の住人、雉-雉ヶ谷の住人）とされる。
sen.e: It is regarded that (dog - people living in Inu-jima Island (inu means dog), monkey - people living in Saruo (saru means monkey), and pheasant - people living in Kijigadani (kiji means pheasant).

It is said that the dog was people living on Inu-jima Island (inu means dog), the monkey was people living in Saruo (saru means monkey), and the pheasant was people living in Kijigadani (kiji means pheasant).

The dog ("inu" in Japanese) that appear in the Momotaro legend is believed to represent the residents of Inu-Jima Island, the monkey ("saru") those living in Saruo and the pheasant ("kiji") those in Kijigadani.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 桃太郎神社鬼無権現熊野神社
sen.e: Momotaro Jinja Kinashigongen Kumano-jinja Shrine
Momotaro Jinja Kinashigongen Kumano-jinja Shrine
Momotaro Jinja Kinashigongen Kumano-jinja Shrine
